title: Reading: Preferring to learn from experience
step_content:
[

Andrew Weist

In this article Andrew Weist contends that the American Expeditionary Forces (AEF) went to battle unprepared and suffered because they believed they had nothing to learn from the mistakes of their Allies. Although the European Allies offered the Americans training, logistical and doctrinal support, the AEF led by its commander, General John Pershing, remained stubbornly independent, and chose instead to learn the costly lessons of war through brutal experience

Weist argues Americans had a deeply engrained cultural aversion to “European” styles of conflict. Americans believed they had a martial culture and they rejected “European-ness.” Despite this cultural inflexibility, most evident on the tactical level, Weist points out that the AEF was able to overcome the vaunted Germans during the Meuse-Argonne Offensive of 1918’. Weist notes that their combat participation in the war was “lightning-fast, lasting for a total of six months.”

Tactically, the AEF downplayed the use of firepower as the method by which to overcome enemy entrenchments, in favour of tactics of open warfare, and the dominance of morale, the rifle and the bayonet. Weist’s survey of the doctrinal journals, and the official doctrines of the American military of the time, also indicates the American tendency to reject the tactical lesson of the Great War, for example, the Infantry Journal, and the US Army’s Infantry Drill Regulations of 1917.

Additionally Weist assesses the issue of training for the AEF, their reliance on the experienced British and French officers, the AEF’s chaotic training schedule, and examples of the weaknesses of the US training system. Using the 32nd Division under the command of General William Haan, and the performance of the 1st and 2nd Divisions in the Second Battle of the Marne as examples, Weist concludes that the Americans went to battle unprepared, but instead of learning from the mistakes of their Allies, they preferred to learn from their experience.

title: Goodbye trench warfare
step_content:
[

During 1917 we see changes in how the battles on the Western Front are fought.

At Messines, a complex British artillery bombardment provided a shield for the soldiers as they advanced and enabled them to capture ground from the Germans and hold it.

At Cambrai, British tanks used their guns and machine guns to support the advance of the infantry. Also at Cambrai, the Germans replied to the British advance with a counter-attack by specially-trained storm troopers. The Germans regained most of the ground they had lost.

The stalemate of trench warfare that had existed on the Western Front since the end of 1914 was being replaced at the end of 1917 with more free-flowing battles.

With the German offensive of March 1918, trench warfare would be no more, and there would be a war of movement until the conflict ended.

This map shows the location of the counter offensives on the Western Front during 1918.

The mystery here is how did this happen? What is clear is that there is no one single reason for the end of trench warfare.

There were many innovations and changes, some large, but many small, that contributed to the return to mobile warfare in the final year of the war.

How did these diverse developments come about? Who instigated them? Were they civilians or were they military? What were the problems they faced and how did they solve them?

Choose one of the changes that led to the end of trench warfare and explain why it is important.

You may also like to discuss why the mobile battles of 1918 like Amiens have been forgotten yet the Somme and Passchendaele are the foundations of the popular memory of the war in the English-speaking world.

Add your thoughts on these matters to the discussion - and remember you can like others’ comments.

title: Reading: Third Ypres: fact and fiction
step_content:
[

Dan Todman

Todman’s article examines how the Third Battle or Ypres or Battle of Passchendaele (12 October – 10 November 1917) had been subsequently represented in books, television documentaries and in popular memory. He argues that Passchendaele is remembered an iconic Great War battle, but as a historical event it has been thoroughly misunderstood.

In the 1920s and 1930s, Ypres became a place of pilgrimage and a site of war memorials such as the Menin Gate. Todman points out that Ypres became a popular destination for British tours to the Western Front. Perhaps more significantly, methods of commemoration were developed for those who could not visit Ypres and the surrounding countryside. These included newspaper articles and Australian artist Will Longstaff’s painting The Menin Gate at Midnight – the print of which became a common feature in Australian homes in the interwar period.

Todman points out that attempts to write Third Ypres into history varied widely in approach, as did the intended audience and the quality of analysis. He argues that the books of the military commentator and journalist, Basil Liddell Hart, and wartime politicians such as Winston Churchill’s The World Crisis and David Lloyd George’s War Memoirs, were influential because they were best sellers and reached large audiences. Conversely, the British Official History volumes published the 1940s had no effect on the memory of Passchendaele.

In the 1960s Leon Wolff’s In Flanders Fields, A. J. P. Taylor’s Illustrated History of the First World War and The Great War television series had all misrepresented the battle, perpetuating the memory of Third Ypres as futile. Todman concludes that, although military historians have produced detailed scholarly histories based on archival research that demonstrate that the battle showed the growing competence of the British Army, the prevailing popular memory will continue.

To read the full article click on the link at the bottom of this page to download a PDF.

What is your view?

As Dan Todman contends, Passchendaele continues to be a place of controversy. Before you move on to the next step you might like to share any connection you have to this town in Belgium. Have you visited the battlefields? If so, tell us about your experience and read those of others, in the comments section.

title: Differing legacies
step_content:
[

The memory of historical events inevitably changes over time. During and immediately after the First World War, there was no collective memory of the war. The people who had lived through the events of 1914 to 1918 may have shared similar experiences, such as soldiering in the trenches, or working in munitions factories, but each person had their own individual memory of the war.

As years passed, the First World War gradually drifted more distantly into the past. The individual memories of the war were replaced by a collective memory shared by a community or nation of people, most of whom had not directly experienced the war.

The memory of the First World War also changed over time for two reasons.

The first was that views of the war have naturally changed in response to subsequent historical events from the Great Depression of the 1930s, the Second World War, the Cold War to the ongoing wars in the Middle East.

The second is that as the First World War passed out of personal memory, poetry and novels played an important role in creating a public memory of the war.

Memories of a major historical event inevitably will change over the time. The mystery for us is to try to understand why did the memory of the First World War in the English-speaking world change in the way it did?

Why is it the British popular memory of the Western Front stops with the Somme in 1916, and ignores the British victories of 1918? The equivalent for the Second World War would be a British memory of that conflict that stops in 1942 with the disastrous raid on Dieppe and Rommel advancing on Egypt, and ignores the British victories in Normandy and Burma in 1944 and the final victory over Germany and Japan.

Why is it that the French public memory of the Western Front is so different from the British public memory?

Why is it that Turks, Australians and New Zealanders remember the Gallipoli campaign as nation-building events rather than pointless and futile battles?

These are questions for which there are no definite answers. However, if we ask the questions, and have the discussion, we can learn new things about the past and those who went before us, and also learn new things about the present and ourselves.

In our final week our historians will guide us to very interesting insights into the memory of the war and how this has been shaped through differing mediums over the last century. Christina Spittel speaks about how certain novels created a particular memory of the war and Keith Jeffery discusses the contrasting ways Irish people have remembered the First World War.

We also consider the memory of the Gallipoli Campaign in some of the nations which served there. We ask “Why is there such a connection to this failed battle to Australia and New Zealand?”
